title: Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, caste, color, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official email address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

title: Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported community leaders responsible enforcement [-email@example.com]. complaints reviewed investigated promptly fairly. community leaders obligated respect privacy security reporter incident.

title: Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders follow Community Impact Guidelines determining consequences action deem violation Code Conduct:

title: Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Use inappropriate language behavior deemed unprofessional unwelcome community. Consequence: private, written warning community leaders, providing clarity around nature violation explanation behavior inappropriate. public apology may requested.

title: Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: violation single incident series actions. Consequence: warning consequences continued behavior. interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, specified period time. includes avoiding interactions community spaces well external channels like social media. Violating terms may lead temporary permanent ban.

title: Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: serious violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior. Consequence: temporary ban sort interaction public communication community specified period time. public private interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, allowed period. Violating terms may lead permanent ban.

title: Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Demonstrating pattern violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior, harassment individual, aggression toward disparagement classes individuals. Consequence: permanent ban sort public interaction within community.

title: Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant, version 2.1, available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/1/code_of_conduct.html. Community Impact Guidelines inspired Mozilla’s code conduct enforcement ladder.

title: Contributing to nanodRop
text: Thank interest contributing nanodRop! welcome contributions community help improve R package analyzing NanoDrop spectrophotometer data.

title: Contributing to nanodRop
text: several ways contribute: Report bugs Suggest features Submit pull requests Improve documentation Please read guide contributing.

title: Contributing to nanodRop
text: find bug, please create issue GitHub following information: clear, descriptive title Steps reproduce bug Expected behavior Actual behavior R version package versions (use sessionInfo()) relevant error messages screenshots

title: Contributing to nanodRop
text: ’d love hear ideas! Please open issue GitHub : clear description proposed feature think useful relevant examples mockups

title: Contributing to nanodRop
text: submit pull request: Fork repository Create feature branch main Make changes Add tests applicable Update documentation Ensure tests pass Submit pull request clear description Please follow existing code style conventions.

title: Contributing to nanodRop
text: set development environment: Install R (version 4.0 later recommended) Install required packages: Clone repository: Load package development mode: Run tests:
code: install.packages(c("devtools", "roxygen2", "testthat", "pkgdown")) git clone https://github.com/yourusername/nanodRop.git devtools::load_all() devtools::test()

title: Contributing to nanodRop
text: Use tidyverse style guide Comment code Write tests new functionality Update NEWS.md changes

title: Advanced Spectral Analysis with nanodRop
text: vignette covers advanced usage nanodRop package, including custom wavelength analysis, statistical comparisons, integration R packages spectral analysis.

title: Advanced Spectral Analysis with nanodRop
text: parse_waves() function allows specify custom wavelength pairs analysis:
code: # Load sample data data <- read_nanodrop(system.file("extdata", "nanodrop_example.tsv", package = "nanodRop"))  # Analyze multiple wavelength pairs custom_pairs <- list(   c(260, 280),  # DNA/RNA peaks   c(300, 400),  # General UV absorption   c(542, 644)   # Custom peaks )  results <- parse_waves(data, wave_pairs = custom_pairs) head(results) #> # A tibble: 6 × 10 #>   samps abs_260 abs_280 diff_260_280 abs_300 abs_400 diff_300_400 abs_542 #>   <chr>   <dbl>   <dbl>        <dbl>   <dbl>   <dbl>        <dbl>   <dbl> #> 1 6 1      3.39    3.13        0.261    2.58   0.93          1.65   0.652 #> 2 6 2      3.49    3.24        0.252    2.70   0.968         1.73   0.686 #> 3 7 1      2.54    2.37        0.178    1.87   0.352         1.51   0.16  #> 4 7 2      2.90    2.74        0.166    2.26   0.722         1.53   0.499 #> 5 8 1      3.53    3.29        0.240    2.68   0.756         1.93   0.517 #> 6 8 2      3.70    3.45        0.253    2.79   0.709         2.08   0.404 #> # ℹ 2 more variables: abs_644 <dbl>, diff_542_644 <dbl>

title: Advanced Spectral Analysis with nanodRop
text: Perform statistical comparisons samples:
code: # Calculate summary statistics for each sample sample_stats <- data %>%   group_by(samps) %>%   summarise(     mean_abs = mean(abs),     max_abs = max(abs),     wavelength_max = waves[which.max(abs)],     auc = sum(abs)  # Area under curve approximation   )  print(sample_stats) #> # A tibble: 24 × 5 #>    samps mean_abs max_abs wavelength_max   auc #>    <chr>    <dbl>   <dbl>          <dbl> <dbl> #>  1 10 1      4.10   23.8            228. 5418. #>  2 10 2      4.87   26.1            229  6433. #>  3 11 1      3.56   26.3            230. 4709. #>  4 11 2      3.17   24.8            228. 4184. #>  5 12 1      3.84   26.4            230  5075. #>  6 12 2      3.88   26.1            230. 5131. #>  7 13 1      2.11   15.9            197  2781. #>  8 13 2      1.38   14.9            194. 1823. #>  9 14 1      2.36   10.5            190. 3122. #> 10 14 2      1.42    9.61           190  1882. #> # ℹ 14 more rows

title: Advanced Spectral Analysis with nanodRop
text: Create informative plots spectral data: Visualization spectral data Visualization spectral data
code: # Spectral overlay plot ggplot(data, aes(x = waves, y = abs, color = samps)) +   geom_line(alpha = 0.7) +   labs(x = "Wavelength (nm)", y = "Absorbance") +   theme_minimal() +   ggtitle("Spectral Comparison") # Heatmap of absorbance across wavelengths wide_data <- dcast(data, samps ~ waves, value.var = "abs") melted_data <- melt(wide_data, id.vars = "samps")  ggplot(melted_data, aes(x = as.factor(variable), y = samps, fill = value)) +   geom_tile() +   scale_fill_viridis_c() +   labs(x = "Wavelength (nm)", y = "Sample", fill = "Absorbance") +   theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 90, hjust = 1))

title: Advanced Spectral Analysis with nanodRop
text: Check data quality identify potential issues:
code: # Check for negative absorbance values negative_abs <- data[data$abs < 0, ] if(nrow(negative_abs) > 0) {   warning("Negative absorbance values detected")   print(negative_abs) } #> Warning: Negative absorbance values detected #>       samps waves    abs #>      <char> <num>  <num> #>   1:    7 1 849.5 -0.006 #>   2:    7 1 850.0 -0.002 #>   3:    9 1 190.0 -0.507 #>   4:    9 1 190.5 -0.481 #>   5:    9 1 191.0 -0.464 #>  ---                     #> 361:   15 3 209.0 -0.019 #> 362:   15 3 209.5 -0.130 #> 363:   15 3 210.0 -0.204 #> 364:   15 3 210.5 -0.067 #> 365:   15 3 211.5 -0.012  # Check wavelength range wavelength_range <- range(data$waves) print(paste("Wavelength range:", wavelength_range[1], "-", wavelength_range[2], "nm")) #> [1] "Wavelength range: 190 - 850 nm"  # Sample completeness check samples_per_wavelength <- table(data$waves) incomplete_samples <- names(samples_per_wavelength[samples_per_wavelength != max(samples_per_wavelength)]) if(length(incomplete_samples) > 0) {   warning("Incomplete wavelength data for some samples") }

title: Advanced Spectral Analysis with nanodRop
text: Combine nanodRop spectroscopy packages: Comparison original smoothed spectra
code: # Example with base R plotting library(nanodRop)  # Smooth spectra using loess smoothed <- data %>%   group_by(samps) %>%   mutate(smoothed_abs = predict(loess(abs ~ waves, span = 0.1)))  # Plot original vs smoothed ggplot(smoothed, aes(x = waves)) +   geom_line(aes(y = abs, color = "Original")) +   geom_line(aes(y = smoothed_abs, color = "Smoothed")) +   facet_wrap(~samps) +   labs(x = "Wavelength (nm)", y = "Absorbance") +   theme_minimal()

title: Advanced Spectral Analysis with nanodRop
text: Process multiple files batch:
code: # List all TSV files in a directory # file_list <- list.files(path = "data/", pattern = "*.tsv", full.names = TRUE)  # Process multiple files (example with single file) batch_results <- list() # for(file in file_list) {   file <- system.file("extdata", "nanodrop_example.tsv", package = "nanodRop")   batch_results[[basename(file)]] <- read_nanodrop(file) # }  # Combine results combined_data <- bind_rows(batch_results, .id = "file") print(table(combined_data$file, combined_data$samps)) #>                        #>                        10 1 10 2 11 1 11 2 12 1 12 2 13 1 13 2 14 1 14 2 15 1 #>   nanodrop_example.tsv 1321 1321 1321 1321 1321 1321 1321 1321 1321 1321 1321 #>                        #>                        15 2 15 3 16 1 16 2  6 1  6 2  7 1  7 2  8 1  8 2  9 1 #>   nanodrop_example.tsv 1321 1321 1321 1321 1321 1321 1321 1321 1321 1321 1321 #>                        #>                         9 2  9 3 #>   nanodrop_example.tsv 1321 1321

title: Advanced Spectral Analysis with nanodRop
code: # Check if expected wavelengths are present expected_waves <- seq(190, 850, by = 0.5) missing_waves <- setdiff(expected_waves, unique(data$waves))  if(length(missing_waves) > 0) {   message("Missing wavelengths: ", paste(missing_waves, collapse = ", ")) } else {   message("All expected wavelengths present") } #> All expected wavelengths present

title: Advanced Spectral Analysis with nanodRop
code: # Clean sample names if needed data_clean <- data %>%   mutate(samps = str_trim(samps))  # Remove extra whitespace  unique(data_clean$samps) #>  [1] "6 1"  "6 2"  "7 1"  "7 2"  "8 1"  "8 2"  "9 1"  "9 2"  "9 3"  "10 1" #> [11] "10 2" "11 1" "11 2" "12 1" "12 2" "13 1" "13 2" "14 1" "14 2" "15 1" #> [21] "15 2" "15 3" "16 1" "16 2"

title: Advanced Spectral Analysis with nanodRop
text: advanced vignette covered: Custom wavelength pair analysis Statistical summaries comparisons Multiple visualization approaches Quality control procedures Integration R packages Batch processing workflows Common troubleshooting scenarios techniques help get NanoDrop spectral data using nanodRop package.

title: Importing and Processing NanoDrop Spectral Data
text: nanodRop package provides tools importing processing spectral data NanoDrop One spectrophotometers. vignette demonstrates use main functions read, parse, analyze spectral data.

title: Importing and Processing NanoDrop Spectral Data
text: primary function importing data read_nanodrop(). takes filepath TSV file exported NanoDrop processes tidy data format. function automatically detects wavelength range (default 190-850 nm) extracts sample information file. returns data.table columns samples, wavelengths, absorbance values.
code: # Load the package library(nanodRop)  # Read a sample NanoDrop TSV file # In this example, we'll use a file included in the package filepath <- system.file("extdata", "nanodrop_example.tsv", package = "nanodRop") data <- read_nanodrop(filepath)  # View the first few rows head(data) #>     samps waves    abs #>    <char> <num>  <num> #> 1:    6 1 190.0 10.666 #> 2:    6 1 190.5 10.782 #> 3:    6 1 191.0 10.853 #> 4:    6 1 191.5 10.877 #> 5:    6 1 192.0 10.866 #> 6:    6 1 192.5 11.105

title: Importing and Processing NanoDrop Spectral Data
text: filepath: Path input TSV file max_wv: Maximum wavelength (default “850.0”) min_wv: Minimum wavelength (default “190.0”) error: Error character check (default “e”)

title: Importing and Processing NanoDrop Spectral Data
text: spectral data loaded, can use parse_waves() extract specific wavelength pairs calculate differences. useful analyzing peaks valleys spectra. function creates columns differences specified wavelength pairs, can used analysis.

title: Importing and Processing NanoDrop Spectral Data
text: dataset: data.frame data.table read_nanodrop() samps_col: Column name samples (default “samps”) waves_col: Column name wavelengths (default “waves”) abs_col: Column name absorbance (default “abs”) wave_pairs: List wavelength pairs analyze (default: c(300,400) c(542,644))

title: Importing and Processing NanoDrop Spectral Data
text: ’s complete workflow analyzing NanoDrop data:
code: # Load and process data data <- read_nanodrop(system.file("extdata", "nanodrop_example.tsv", package = "nanodRop"))  # Parse wavelength differences results <- parse_waves(data)  # Basic summary statistics summary(results) #>     samps              abs_300          abs_400         diff_300_400    #>  Length:24          Min.   : 1.807   Min.   : 0.3520   Min.   :-5.885   #>  Class :character   1st Qu.: 2.692   1st Qu.: 0.9585   1st Qu.: 1.625   #>  Mode  :character   Median : 7.551   Median : 1.7560   Median : 2.345   #>                     Mean   : 9.219   Mean   : 4.7457   Mean   : 4.473   #>                     3rd Qu.:13.745   3rd Qu.: 4.3907   3rd Qu.: 7.972   #>                     Max.   :23.889   Max.   :29.1990   Max.   :16.975   #>     abs_542           abs_644         diff_542_644     #>  Min.   : 0.1450   Min.   : 0.0830   Min.   :0.05500   #>  1st Qu.: 0.5192   1st Qu.: 0.3977   1st Qu.:0.08425   #>  Median : 0.6870   Median : 0.5340   Median :0.14050   #>  Mean   : 2.5560   Mean   : 2.1935   Mean   :0.36254   #>  3rd Qu.: 1.4948   3rd Qu.: 0.9510   3rd Qu.:0.50325   #>  Max.   :24.6950   Max.   :23.8760   Max.   :1.51200  # Plot a sample spectrum library(ggplot2) sample_spectrum <- data[data$samps == unique(data$samps)[1], ] ggplot(sample_spectrum, aes(x = waves, y = abs)) +   geom_line() +   labs(x = "Wavelength (nm)", y = "Absorbance", title = "Sample Spectrum") +   theme_minimal()

title: Importing and Processing NanoDrop Spectral Data
text: package handles multiple samples single file automatically:
code: # Data with multiple samples multi_sample_data <- read_nanodrop(system.file("extdata", "nanodrop_example.tsv", package = "nanodRop"))  # See all unique samples unique(multi_sample_data$samps) #>  [1] "6 1"  "6 2"  "7 1"  "7 2"  "8 1"  "8 2"  "9 1"  "9 2"  "9 3"  "10 1" #> [11] "10 2" "11 1" "11 2" "12 1" "12 2" "13 1" "13 2" "14 1" "14 2" "15 1" #> [21] "15 2" "15 3" "16 1" "16 2"  # Plot all samples ggplot(multi_sample_data, aes(x = waves, y = abs, color = samps, group = samps)) +   geom_line() +   labs(x = "Wavelength (nm)", y = "Absorbance", title = "Multiple Sample Spectra") +   theme_minimal() +   theme(legend.position = "bottom")

title: Importing and Processing NanoDrop Spectral Data

title: Tools for Importing and Processing NanoDrop One Spectral Data
text: Overview Features Installation Quick Start Examples API Reference Contributing License Citation

title: Tools for Importing and Processing NanoDrop One Spectral Data
text: nanodRop R package designed simplify import processing spectral data files exported NanoDrop One spectrophotometer. converts raw TSV files tidy CSV formats ready downstream analysis R, making spectral data analysis accessible efficient. package handles complexities NanoDrop file formats, including parsing multiple samples, wavelength ranges, absorbance measurements, providing clean, analyzable output.

title: Tools for Importing and Processing NanoDrop One Spectral Data
text: Easy Import: Direct import NanoDrop One TSV files Data Cleaning: Automatic handling error indicators data validation Tidy Output: Converts spectral data tidy data frames suitable analysis Flexible Parsing: Customizable wavelength ranges sample processing Peak Analysis: Built-functions spectral peak valley calculations R Integration: Seamlessly integrates tidyverse ecosystem

title: Tools for Importing and Processing NanoDrop One Spectral Data

code: # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("beabock/nanodRop")

title: nanodRop 0.1.0
text: Initial release nanodRop package Added read_nanodrop() function importing NanoDrop spectral data Added parse_waves() function analyzing wavelength differences Added example datasets ds ds1 Comprehensive test suite testthat Package documentation pkgdown Vignettes basic data import advanced analysis

title: nanodRop 0.1.0
text: Easy import NanoDrop One TSV files Automatic data cleaning validation Tidy data output compatible tidyverse Flexible wavelength analysis capabilities Multiple sample support Integration ggplot2 visualization
